title: Quiz 2: Community Health II, HIS, HCDS & Nutrition
description: Diploma in Community Health Nursing - Year 1 Semester 2

questions.question: The sustainable development goal (SDG) responsible for health is?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: b) SDG No. 3 Explanation: SDG 3 is titled "Good Health and Well-being" and aims to ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages. Why other options are incorrect: a) SDG No. 1: No Poverty. c) SDG No. 7: Affordable and Clean Energy. d) SDG No. 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth.

questions.question: Socio-economic factors that have bearing on health include:

options.text: a) Education, live birth, blood test

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Housing, education, food Explanation: Socio-economic factors (Social Determinants of Health) include conditions in which people are born, grow, live, work, and age. Housing, education levels, and access to food (nutrition/security) are classic socio-economic determinants. Why other options are incorrect: a, b, d: Include medical/clinical factors (blood test, live birth, fertility) which are biological or clinical indicators, not strictly socio-economic factors.

questions.question: The principles of primary health care are:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Accessibility, availability, affordable Explanation: The classic principles of PHC (the "4 As" + Participation) usually include Accessibility, Affordability, Availability, and Acceptability (along with Community Participation). Option C captures the core logistical and economic principles best among the choices. Note: While 'Participation' is a key pillar, option B's phrasing "accepted" typically refers to Acceptability. Option C is the most standard grouping of the "A" principles.

questions.question: The primary health care elements that were added to the ones identified at Alma Ata conference in Kenya are:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Mental health Explanation: The original Alma Ata declaration (1978) listed 8 essential elements (Education, Water/Sanitation, Nutrition, MCH/FP, Immunization, Endemic diseases, Treatment of common diseases, Essential drugs). Kenya expanded these to include Mental Health and Dental Health. Why other options are incorrect: a, b, d: Health education, Nutrition, and MCH were all part of the original 8 elements.

questions.question: Activities of primary prevention of disease includes?

options.text: a) Screening, mass treatment and campaigns

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: d) Medical checkup, adequate nutrition Explanation: Primary prevention aims to prevent disease before it occurs. This includes health promotion (adequate nutrition, health education) and specific protection (immunization). While option C contains immunization, "case finding" is typically secondary prevention. Option D combines general health promotion (nutrition) and monitoring (checkups to maintain health). Analysis of Options: a) Screening: Secondary prevention (early detection). b) Follow up: Tertiary prevention; Screening is Secondary. c) Case finding: Secondary prevention. d) Nutrition: Primary prevention (Health Promotion). Note: Immunization is the classic example of Primary Prevention (Specific Protection). However, since option C pairs it with "Case finding" (Secondary), option D is often chosen in these exams if "Medical checkup" implies "well-baby clinic" or routine monitoring, combined with nutrition. If strict definitions apply, Immunization is the strongest Primary intervention.

questions.question: The pre-visiting activities for home visiting are:

options.text: b) Explaining the reasons for visit

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: d) Gathering information Explanation: The pre-visit phase involves preparation before making contact. This includes reviewing client records, gathering necessary equipment, contacting the client to schedule (if applicable), and gathering information about the client's history and location. Why other options are incorrect: a, b: Observing the environment and explaining the reason for the visit occur during the visit (entry phase).

questions.question: The key players in the implementation of Kenya essential package of health (KEPH) in the community are:

options.text: a) Community owned resource person (CORPs), Community Health Extension Workers (CHEWs)
b) Health management team, Community Health Extension Workers.
c) Community owned resource persons, non-governmental organization.
d) Community Health Extension workers, Faith-Based Organizations.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: a) Community owned resource person (CORPs), Community Health Extension Workers (CHEWs) Explanation: At Level 1 (Community Strategy) of KEPH, the primary implementers are the Community Health Extension Workers (CHEWs) (now often called Community Health Assistants/Officers) who supervise Community Health Volunteers (CHVs) and CORPs.

questions.question: The Kenya health strategies investment plan was initiated to run from:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: b) 2012- 2030 Explanation: This likely refers to the overarching Kenya Health Policy 2014-2030 which aligns with Vision 2030. While Investment Plans (KHSSP) are typically 5-year cycles (e.g., 2014-2018), the long-term strategic horizon is often cited as up to 2030.

questions.question: When health care is geographically financially within easy reach to the entire community the services is said to be:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Accessible to the community Explanation: Accessibility encompasses geographical (distance) and financial (affordability) reach. It means services are located where people can get to them and priced so people can pay for them. Why other options are incorrect: a) Available: Means the services exist and function (hours, staff). b) Acceptable: Means the culture and methods are approved by the community. d) Affordable: Refers only to cost, not geography.

questions.question: Indicate whether the following statements are true or false:
State any five (5) principles of home visiting. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Planning: Visits should be planned with a clear purpose and objectives. Flexibility: The nurse should be flexible to adapt to the family's situation and needs. Technical competence: The nurse must possess the necessary skills and knowledge. Safety: Ensuring the safety of both the nurse and the client/family. Confidentiality: Respecting the privacy of the family's information. Documentation: Recording findings and interventions accurately. Regularity: Visits should be regular based on client needs. Evaluation: Outcomes of the visit should be evaluated against objectives.

questions.question: Explain three (3) pillars of vision 2030. (6 marks)
questions.explanation: Economic Pillar: Aims to achieve an average economic growth rate of 10% per annum and sustain the same until 2030 to move Kenya into a middle-income country. Social Pillar: Aims to build a just and cohesive society with social equity in a clean and secure environment. This includes sectors like Health, Education, and Housing. Political Pillar: Aims to realize a democratic political system that is issue-based, people-centered, result-oriented, and accountable to the public.

questions.question: State the KEPH (Kenya Essential Package of Health) life cycle cohorts. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Cohort 1: Pregnancy and the newborn (up to 2 weeks). Cohort 2: Early Childhood (2 weeks to 5 years). Cohort 3: Late Childhood (6 to 12 years). Cohort 4: Adolescents and Youth (13 to 24 years). Cohort 5: Adulthood (25 to 59 years). Cohort 6: Elderly (60+ years).

questions.question: State four (4) key implementers of primary health care in Kenya. (4 marks)
questions.explanation: Community Health Volunteers (CHVs): Frontline workers at the household level. Community Health Extension Workers (CHEWs) / CHAs: Technical supervisors of CHVs. Health Facility Management Committees (HFMC): Community representatives overseeing facility operations. Community Health Committees (CHCs): Provide oversight at the community unit level. County and Sub-County Health Management Teams (CHMT/SCHMT): Provide leadership and resources.

questions.question: You have been posted to county X where you are to initiate health programme.
questions.explanation: To promote the health and well-being of school-going children. To detect and treat health problems early (screening). To create a healthy and safe school environment. To provide health education and foster healthy habits. To prevent the spread of communicable diseases within the school.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a function of carbohydrates:

options.text: a) Protein sparing with adequate supply protein is not used for energy.
b) Synthesis of enzymes, plasma proteins, immunoglobulin and some hormones.
c) Participation in all the chemical reactions that occur in the body.
d) It is a catalyst in the metabolism of amino acids.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: a) Protein sparing with adequate supply protein is not used for energy. Explanation: The primary function of carbohydrates is energy provision. When sufficient carbohydrates are available, the body uses them for fuel, "sparing" protein so it can be used for its primary functions like tissue repair and growth rather than being burned for energy.

questions.question: Fat soluble vitamins include:

options.text: a) Vitamin E, K, C and D
b) Vitamin A,D, E and K
c) Vitamin A, C, D and K
d) Vitamin A, D, E and C

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: b) Vitamin A, D, E and K Study Tip: Remember "ADEK" for fat-soluble vitamins. Vitamins B and C are water-soluble.

questions.question: In starvation, the first nutrient to be depleted in the body is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Carbohydrates Explanation: The body first uses circulating blood glucose, then glycogen stores (carbohydrates) in the liver and muscles. Once these are depleted (usually within 24 hours), the body shifts to burning fats (ketosis) and eventually proteins.

questions.question: The main function of vitamin E is:

options.text: d) Maintenance of structure and function of epithelia.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: b) Anti-oxidant activity Explanation: Vitamin E (Tocopherol) is a powerful antioxidant that protects cell membranes from oxidative damage by free radicals.

questions.question: Which of the following is destroyed by heating and freezing:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: d) Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Explanation: Vitamin B1 is heat labile (sensitive to heat) and can be destroyed by cooking. Vitamin C is also very sensitive to heat and oxidation. Among the options provided, Thiamine (B1) is known to be unstable at high temperatures and high pH.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a function of calcium:

options.text: a) Hardening of bone and teeth
b) Maintenance of electrolyte balance in the body.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: a) Hardening of bone and teeth Explanation: While Calcium is involved in nerve transmission (C) and muscle contraction (D), its primary structural role where 99% of body calcium is stored is in the mineralization (hardening) of bones and teeth.

questions.question: Deficiency of iodine results to:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: b) Goiter Explanation: Iodine is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis. Deficiency causes the thyroid gland to enlarge (Goiter) in an attempt to capture more iodine.

questions.question: The characteristics of marasmus include:

options.text: a) Oedema in the legs, feet and lower arms and hands.
b) The face looks swollen and round (moon face)
c) Severe wasting because the body breaks down muscles.
d) The child has less hair than usual, at pulls out easily and may be pale.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Severe wasting because the body breaks down muscles. Explanation: Marasmus is caused by a severe deficiency of calories and protein (starvation), leading to gross wasting of muscle and fat (old man appearance). Oedema and moon face are characteristic of Kwashiorkor.

questions.question: Wasting is:

options.text: a) Having a low weight for length (WFLz) of less than – 2Z scores.
b) Having a weight for age (WFAz) Z – score of less than 2Z scores
c) Having a length height for age (hFaz) Z-score of less than -2 Z scores.
d) Having a low weight for length/height (WFLz) of less than – 3Z scores

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: a) Having a low weight for length (WFLz) of less than – 2Z scores. Explanation: Moderate Wasting is defined as Weight-for-Height/Length between -2 and -3 Z-scores. Severe Wasting is < -3 Z-scores. Option A correctly defines the threshold for wasting generally (below -2SD). Option C describes stunting. Option B describes underweight.

questions.question: First step in budgeting is:

options.text: a) Calculate the total cost of the items.
b) Establish the period of time that money will be required to feed the family.
c) Establish the amount of money available.
d) Select the ones that will be friendly to your budget and will also be rich in nutrients

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Establish the amount of money available. Explanation: Effective budgeting begins with knowing your income or the total resources available before you can plan expenses.

questions.question: State five (5) principles of meal planning. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Adequacy: Providing sufficient energy and essential nutrients. Balance: Consuming foods from all food groups in correct proportions. Calorie Control (Energy Control): Balancing energy intake with energy expenditure. Moderation: Avoiding excessive consumption of fat, salt, and sugar. Variety: Eating different foods within each food group to ensure broad nutrient intake.

questions.question: List four (4) methods of nutritional assessment. (4 marks)
questions.explanation: Mnemonic: ABCD Anthropometric methods: Height, weight, MUAC, BMI. Biochemical methods: Lab tests (e.g., hemoglobin, serum albumin). Clinical methods: Physical exam for signs of deficiency (e.g., pallor, edema). Dietary methods: 24-hour recall, food frequency questionnaires.

questions.question: State four (4) pillars of food security. (4 marks)
questions.explanation: Availability: Sufficient quantities of food available on a consistent basis. Access: Having sufficient resources to obtain appropriate foods for a nutritious diet. Utilization: Appropriate use based on knowledge of basic nutrition and care, as well as adequate water and sanitation. Stability: Availability and access must be consistent over time (no risk of losing access due to shocks).

questions.question: State four (4) reasons for therapeutic diet. (4 marks)
questions.explanation: To maintain good nutritional status. To correct nutritional deficiencies (e.g., iron for anemia). To provide rest to a specific organ (e.g., low fat for gall bladder disease). To adjust the body's weight (gain or loss). To facilitate digestion and absorption (e.g., soft diet).

questions.question: With an aid of a diagram, illustrate the nutrition infection cycle. (5 marks)
questions.explanation:
Description of the Cycle: The cycle illustrates the bidirectional relationship between malnutrition and infection. [ Malnutrition ]
           ^      |
           |      v
(Decreased)|   (Lowered Immunity)
(Appetite )|      |
           |      v
      [ Infection  ] Inadequate Dietary Intake: Leads to weight loss, growth faltering, and lowered immunity. Disease/Infection: Lowered immunity makes the body more susceptible to infections. Impact of Infection: Infection causes loss of appetite (anorexia), malabsorption of nutrients, altered metabolism, and increased nutrient needs. Result: This worsens the malnutrition, creating a vicious cycle.

questions.question: Master V aged 9 months is admitted in pediatric ward with severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
questions.explanation: Nutritional value: Contains all essential nutrients in the right proportions. Immunity: Provides antibodies (IgA) protecting against infections. Digestibility: Easily digested and absorbed by the infant's immature gut. Bonding: Promotes emotional bonding between mother and baby. Temperature: Always at the right temperature. Cost-effective: It is free and requires no preparation.
